    "there are two and a half main examples of reproducing kernel spaces of analytic function .",
    "one is the fock ",
    "segal  bargmann ( fsb ) space and others ( one and a half)the bergman and hardy spaces . the first space is generated by the heisenberg group  , two others  by the group @xmath0  @xcite*  4.2 ( this explains our way of counting ) .",
    "those spaces have the following properties , which make their study particularly pleasant and fruitful :    1 .   [",
    "item : group ] there is a group , which acts transitively on functions domain .",
    "item : reproducing - kernel ] there is a reproducing kernel .",
    "[ item : spac - cons - holom ] the space consists of holomorphic functions .",
    "furthermore , for fsb space there is the following property :    1 .",
    "[ item : uncertainity ] the reproducing kernel is generated by a function , which minimises the uncertainty for coordinate and momentum observables .",
    "it is known , that a transformation group is responsible for the appearance of the reproducing kernel  @xcite*thm .",
    "this paper shows that the last two properties are equivalent and connected to the group as well .",
    "in quantum mechanics  @xcite*  1.1 , an observable ( self - adjoint operator on a hilbert space @xmath1 ) @xmath2 produces the expectation value @xmath3 on a state ( a unit vector ) @xmath4 by @xmath5 .",
    "then , the dispersion is evaluated as follow : @xmath6 the next theorem links obstructions of exact simultaneous measurements with non - commutativity of observables .",

    "equality holds precisely when @xmath14 is a solution of @xmath15 for some real @xmath16 .",
    "the proof is well - known  @xcite*  1.3 , but it is short , instructive and relevant for the following discussion , thus we include it in full .",

    "this function is in the state space @xmath25 .",
    "it is common to say that the gaussian @xmath38 represents the ground state , which minimises the uncertainty of coordinate and momentum .",
    "the following object is common in quantum mechanics  @xcite , signal processing , harmonic analysis  @xcite , operator theory  @xcite and many other areas  @xcite .",
    "therefore , it has various names  @xcite : coherent states , wavelets , matrix coefficients , etc . in the most fundamental situation  @xcite*ch .  8 , we start from an irreducible unitary representation @xmath46 of a lie group @xmath47 in a hilbert space @xmath1 . for a vector @xmath48 ( called mother wavelet , vacuum state , etc . ) , we define the map @xmath49 from @xmath1 to a space of functions on @xmath47 by : @xmath50(g)=\\tilde{v}(g):={\\left\\langle v,{\\ifcase 0{\\rho^{}_{}}\\or { \\breve{\\rho}^{}_{}}\\or { \\tilde{\\rho}^{}_{}}\\fi}(g)f           \\right\\rangle\\ifx\\relax\\relax\\else_{\\relax}\\fi}.\\ ] ] under the above assumptions , @xmath51 is a bounded continuous function on @xmath47 .",

    ", none of admissible vectors has an advantage over others .",

  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we describe a connection between minimal uncertainty states and holomorphy - type conditions on the images of the respective wavelet transforms . </S>",
    "<S> the most familiar example is the fock  </S>",
    "<S> segal  </S>",
    "<S> bargmann transform generated by the gaussian , however , this also occurs under more general assumptions . </S>"
  ]
